abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely; the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that with
            appropriate technical assistance and application of policy
            guidelines, the District Development Committee (DDCs) have
            proven that they are capable of undertaking planning and
            implementing rural road programs. Within His Majesty's
            Government of Nepal (HMGN's) decentralization policy
            framework and guidelines and implementation modalities, Bank
            assistance for rural infrastructure can be effectively
            provided. With close monitoring and effective planning
            tools, local capacity can be harnessed in project selection
            and implementation and local political incentives can be
            minimized in project selection. Decentralization of
            responsibilities to local governments is most effective by
            applying new institutions and "rules of the game"
            that can change the incentive structure and the political
            economy of local bodies. Community-based organizations
            (CBOs) offer a viable institutional option for carrying out
            small civil works, but they require upfront mobilization and
            technical support to ensure timely and quality delivery of
            outputs. The benefits of small rural road works are mostly
            savings in travel time, improved access to markets, and
            social service facilities. The provision of technical
            assistance needs to give strong emphasis on direct support
            to DDCs and CBOs. It is possible to undertake development
            activities in conflict-affected districts, if implementation
            is done by beneficiaries and community groups, use of
            project funds is transparent, and neutral social mobilizers
            are hired to facilitate project implementation. DTMPs should
            include all priority rural transport infrastructure,
            including new construction, upgrading, rehabilitation and
            maintenance. Appropriate environmental assessment should be
            carried out for all sub-projects involving rehabilitation/upgrading.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Infrastructure Project for
            Nepal aims to strengthen the institutional capacity of a
            decentralized local governance system in its planning and
            managing capabilities to improve the quality, efficiency,
            and sustainability of rural roads in selected districts with
            active participation of project beneficiaries. There are
            four project components. The first component supports
            routine maintenance, periodic maintenance, rehabilitation
            and spot improvement of existing district roads/trails and
            other rural infrastructure in eight selected districts. The
            second component provides supervision and design of civil
            works. The third component procures basic equipment for
            logistical support including four-wheel drive pickups,
            motorcycles, and computers and photocopiers. The fourth
            component funds consultancy services to help the
            institutional capacity of development departments and
            entities at the local and national levels, trains staff and
            contractors, funds project monitoring and evaluation,
            including a community-based performance monitoring system.
